title-group.article-title: Tracing Gender in the Story of the Oven of Akhnai: The Beit Midrash between the Divine and Female Realms

abstract.p: This paper explores thesugyain the Babylonian Talmud that includes the story of the Oven of Akhnai, in BTBaba metzi‘‘a58b––59b, expanding earlier studies by Jeffrey Rubenstein and Charlotte Fonrobert. It shows that two scriptural quotations involving, respectively, David and Tamar, situated in the first part of thesugya, anticipate the subsequent story and clarify how it functions as a ““foundation myth”” of the Beit Midrash (Fonrobert), and, therefore, of male identity (Boyarin). I suggest that the entiresugyaconstructs male identity by way of contrast with two ““others,”” the divine and the female realms, which are excluded from the Law-making process. The danger of verbal wrong, however, reveals the necessity of reintroducing the excluded ““others.”” The text achieves this by recognizing the existence of a transcendent justice, and by making Tamar, a foreign and female character with no access to the Law, a model of delicacy in verbal communication.

According to Deut. 22:20–21, the punishment of a bride found not to be a virgin is stoning. The levirate law appears in Deut. 25:5–10. However, as Menn, in Judah and Tamar (above, note 21), pp.55–64, points out, Genesis 38 displays many differences with this law. In Deuteronomy, the purpose of the levirate union is to preserve the “name” of the deceased man, while in Gen. 38 the union is supposed, more specifically, to produce offspring for Er. Moreover, Gen. 38 seems to suppose not that the dead man's brother should take his sister-in-law as a wife (contrary to Deut. 25:5), but only that he should have intercourse with her until a son is born. Finally, Judah's role in Gen. 38 is striking, as the levirate law does not mention any role for the deceased's father.

Interestingly for the analysis of gender in the story, the figures of both Tamar and Ima Shalom are absent in the version of the Jerusalem Talmud. We may surmise that the figure of Ima Shalom was introduced at the same time as the first part of thesugya, including the example of Tamar.
